subtitle: Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Our topic today is Growing Up with Rex Stanford.
Rex Stanford was a well-known parapsychologist who died last year.
My guest is Rex's identical twin brother, Ray Stanford.
Ray has had a career as a psychic and trans-channeler.
He is the author of books such as Speak,
Shining Stranger, The Spirit, Unto the Churches,
and The Fatima Prophecy.
He has also established a reputation as a
UFO researcher and is the author of the book
Socorro Saucer.
In addition, he has established a career as a paleontologist.
In fact, he's used his intuitive skills to make a long series of amazing discoveries,
so much so that The Washington Post Sunday
Magazine did a cover story about him calling
him the Amazing Dino Man.
Now if you haven't seen the previous interview
with Ray titled The Blue Apple, I encourage
you to view it.
In fact, I'm going to link to it right now in
the upper right-hand corner of your screen.
If you have the right equipment, you'll be able to link directly to it.
I recommend that you watch that video,
it'll make this one all the more meaningful.
The interview with Ray took place at his home in Maryland.
I can tell you, it's the only time I got on an
airplane and flew halfway across the country
just to conduct an interview or a series
really of interviews for new thinking allowed.
I'm delighted that I did it and now I'll switch
over to the video we made on that occasion.
Why don't we start talking about your very earliest memories of Rex?
He's already explained it, he's like your other half.
We're always there together and so I'm not sure how separately we thought, although we
were always from the start, it was obvious to
me that his personality and I were different
in almost opposite polar ways.
I don't recall ever much the way of fights or fusses.
I'm sure we must have had some somewhere
along the way, but I guess you repressed those
kind of things more than the more positive things of life.
It's hard to explain at that age, but even then, there was that distinct personality
difference in which I was interested in things
and rocks and things I could analyze that
are physical things that I could analyze.
And Rex was more, I guess, I don't know, an
abstract thinker, but early on I know he became
very, very fascinated as soon as... Well, of
course, he had been influenced by the fact
that my mother talked frequently about how, and she didn't use the word, but psychic,
her mother was Cornelia Neely, as people called
her, we called her Big Mama as her grandmother,
and she's a really sweet lady.
But she just had showed all of her life and my mother just took it for granted.
And Rex, I guess, took more of an interest in
that even the night I knew that I had things
happening that must be psychic, but as a kid, I didn't know a name for it.
I mean, I just remember early on the first name in science I ever hear of Rex was J.B.
Ryan, even when he was quite pretty young, I don't remember how young.
And yet here I was instead interested in space
travel, and I started building these rockets
of which you saw a couple of little rocket engine nozzles a while ago.
I mean, I was just oriented toward space.
He was oriented toward the inner space, and
I say I was oriented toward the outer space,
the things out there, and of course, while
in 1947, I just grabbed onto the reports that
began with Kenneth Arnold, but Rex never, I mean, he found them interesting.
He didn't reject them.
He was interested in them, but he never got
absorbed and absolutely obsessed with it like
I did.
And while I dared to go to the principal's wife in the school and say, when I grow up,
I'm going to find out what the flying saucers
are, I'm going to tell the whole world Rex
wasn't even on the scene.
He didn't, I mean, he didn't reject my interest
at all, but he just didn't seem as interested
in these space things as always internal thought
and psychology, and of course, parapsychology.
But Rex did travel with you to Peru back in, it must have been, what, the early 60s?
This was 57.
Yeah, it was anywhere, right out of high
school, we'd graduated from high school in 56.
Yeah, and it was because, if I recall correctly, Williamson?
Yes, George Hunt Williamson was doing voice channeling and claimed to be coming data.
He didn't talk about, as my readings did, when I got into that, the unconscious Ray
Stafford didn't talk about that.
He had always claimed to be external entities
of some sort, some of which, of course, I
think came out of Madame Blavatsky or Theosophy or something, I'm not sure.
But anyway, for some reason, Rex and I both fell for it, right out of high school.
I guess you're looking for some kind of adventure
to start with right when you get out of high
school.
None of us had immediate plans to go to college
in the first place, we were in kind of tight
financial straits because my father had been
re-hospitalized because of tuberculosis.
And so we didn't think, I don't even know how we got the money to go to Peru.
That itself was a miracle of some sort.
But Rex was there believing the whole thing,
but it's hard to explain, in fact, it's
hard now for me to imagine that he would have
been there, that he would not have separated
enough intellectually that he wouldn't have accepted that kind of thing as I did.
We need to go back, I suppose, to the UFO sightings that you both experienced and in
the presence of your friends.
That's right.
That's right.
Of course, we had this spectacular event,
really, of September 18th, 1956, and was out
on the high desert of California right within
the BB gunshot of Van Tassel's giant rock.
It was on a sunshiny day, September 18th, 1956, and I don't recall it.
I don't think Van Tassel was around that day, I think he'd gone somewhere.
But we were there with a friend, Michael J.
Robesicki, Jr., and we also experienced this
rather remarkable thing, and Rex was in on this.
He fully accepted that we had gotten, or that
I had gotten, at least, a telepathic message
that we could be contacted.
We would encounter a UFO, an alien craft,
whatever you want to think of them as being,
on the desert that day, and I felt kind of led in telling us where to go and so on and
so forth.
We were going to ride along with this, and I'm
glad he did, because then he got to witness
and see for himself the reality of this.
But even in that little first film, that eight
millimeter film, as you saw, we could see
through binoculars more than we could of that
camera, and we could see clearly a golden
crescent shape looking like it was a crescent
shape, but with a glowing field around it
that was pulsing like a jellyfish in water.
So in this film, as you saw in one frame, you can make out the dipolar, let's say,
donut-shaped visible part of the field that I
know now was made visible by plasma interacting
in the magnetic field of the craft, and we,
at the time, even felt it was visible evidence
of magnetic field.
We didn't know the word plasma, and so and
so, but we saw it, and it was very exciting.
We talked about how it looked like a jellyfish
field, and I mean, you could see it that well.
Even, you know, right with our eyes and then
the binoculars, and fortunately, the camera
recorded it, but I'm so glad that Rex went along because then he remained in harmony
and full acceptance of my bigger involvement
with UFOs and instruments to record UFOs
while he's dealing with the inner man, the psychological, it was probably helpful to
me that the other side of me was out there in the inner, and I think that he in a way
was in a way out into the outer, by way of my involvement.
So it was a symbiotic relationship, perhaps, you can say.
We were never at ends on that at all, and even when we withdrew from this crazy thing
of Rick Williamson, as he was called, George
Hunt Williamson, Rick Williamson, in this
priori, Priotorio Torres de Los Santos, he
called it all Saint's priori, well, I didn't
knowingly meet any saints there, but it was,
you know, it was in the boondocks east of
the Rio Mayo outside of a little town that didn't even have electricity or water back
in those days.
Why they chose that location, I don't know,
but it may have been a stupid choice, except
it was a good choice for me because I got to
see along, I think, with Rex and definitely
at least one other person on the patio that day, as I've said, a spectacular black dome
disk with red glowing, we now know plasma, swirling, if you're looking up at it this
way, it's running clockwise.
Now, to be clear, that observation was in Peru, is that right?
That was in Peru, in Muyabamba, east of the Rio Mayo, in the state of San Martin, and
at the time I said it was hardly even a town
on the map, it was so small yet, by an unpaved,
they had an unpaved runway that DC-3s could take you into and out of, and that's how
we got in and that's how we eventually got
out, was that way, but it was even an unpaved,
I'm pretty certain that it was even just a dirt runway, imagining a DC-3 in the desert
and going to some kooky community, but we were open to size stuff, it just, we hadn't
had enough experience to learn to discern
what was real and what was part of the fantasy
of the subconscious.
Let's go back now to the sighting at Giant Rock.
You had some sort of an impression in advance
of that sighting, that if you go there you
will see something.
That's right, absolutely.
We really believed that.
How did it come to you?
It's hard to say, a knowing is just a knowing,
and you feel my interpretation, at least
at the time, was that it was directed, that it was coming from alien beings.
I didn't feel I knew him personally, but I
felt they were telling me, you know, we will
meet you, we'll give you a show out there, so to speak.
And if I understand correctly, you traveled from Texas to California.
Well, yes, of course, we lived in Texas, but
we went out to California, and for that time
we were living in Los Angeles, we got an apartment
there, and I don't remember anything about
how we even financed that, since we didn't
have jobs, and we were just out of high school.
Well, were we out of high school as a separate 1856?
Okay, I guess that's the September, right after we graduated in May, I suppose, from
W.V. Ray High School in Corpus Christi.
And were there any sightings prior to the one in Giant Rock?
I think there were, but of course that wouldn't stand out so much.
You know, we've got a film and a nice visible
magnetic field that keeps that high in your
memory.
And also, it's like, I mean, I don't remember what we may have seen before.
I'm sure there were some things, but maybe
there were at night, but it's a broad daylight,
you know, and we're getting a film of it, and there are three of us there seeing it.
We know we're not hallucinating, and the camera didn't hallucinate.
And it was, let's say, it was, in a way, in a sense, to really getting us into ufology.
It was the breaking of virginity of any skepticism whatsoever.
When we saw that, I mean, I wasn't skeptical.
We were responding to this, and Rex
accepted that Ray is getting these messages.
In fact, he, too, felt that he could feel these messages, too.
But he just didn't seem to feel them as graphically as I did.
But from a parapsychological point of view, receiving the message, traveling hundreds
of miles, and then going to the location where
you saw the UFO is pretty clearly a sigh,
even.
Well, I'm not sure that it was that message that brought us to California.
It may have been George Adamsky, not as a
personal effort, but because we believed George
Adamsky at that stage.
We even have, stupidly, in our little book, Look Up, the first book we came on, we even
have a drawing of his so-called Venusian spacecraft,
which was nothing but a small man made of
you, about so big, apparently.
But that drove us out there.
But while we were out there, I think was when I received this strong impression.
And interesting enough, I did not conceptualize
it or feel it in the context of what Adamsky
had described in flying saucers that had landed or later inside the spaceship.
It was more that it was alien beings, but it
wasn't in a sense like, hey, we're Adamsky's
buddies, we'll meet you on the day.
It wasn't that.
It felt somehow independent.
I can't explain it.
I don't know if I even said it that way at that time.
But it just felt like it was alien beings that somehow I had an inner kinship with.
They knew me to some extent and that I knew them.
That's hard to explain.
I wouldn't take any further than that because
I don't know if there is any further than
that.
But I do believe that whoever these occupants
are, that they are better at reading our minds
than we are at reading theirs.
So let me try to be as clear as I can that before you even saw the UFO at Giant Rock,
before you even felt you had an intuition
to go there for the purpose of seeing a UFO,
you were already interested in the writings of George Adams.
Oh, yes, yes, absolutely.
You and Rex both.
Yes.
I'd have to check the dates, but there was
also a man named Truman Bethram that I never
– I can't recall that I ever decided that he was a hoax.
I wouldn't say today to say that he was genuine.
But I'd need to reread the book and think it over and see about my feelings about it
today.
And I know that Rex had read the Damsky
stuff, but I don't know if he ever read Truman
Bethram or some of the other material people.
Of course, there was George Van Tassel, as we said.
But as far as I know, I don't recall – and he
seemed to have been more of a psychic thing,
and I don't recall – he never claimed to have taken any photographs at all.
And Bethram never claimed to have taken any photographs.
But at the time, I definitely believed in Truman Bethram.
And I think Rex probably kind of accepted
it, but never ate it with a spoon like I did.
You know, I mean, I really – the idea that a
real spaceship could come down and something
might be thinking about you and respond to
your thoughts and do something, or maybe even
come out and communicate with you.
Yes, Rex accepted that, but it wasn't as dear to his heart as mine was.
He was – and like I said, we were kind of opposites.
And I was the more experiential, and he was more interior, I guess you could say.
And yet it was I who interiorly felt these
messages more deeply, I think, than Rex did.
But he did definitely acknowledge – he said, oh, yes, Ray, I can feel it.
We've got to go out.
They're going to be out there.
I remember him saying that.
At this point in time, I think it's fair to say both you and Rex would agree that
Adamsky was, if not 100 percent, was largely a fraud.
I would say 110 percent fraud.
I mean, that sounds funny, but absolutely
every photograph he ever claimed to have taken,
as far as I know, was fake.
And I think I have pretty good evidence and things I saw even in his own studio.
So what I find intriguing here is the possibility
that this fraud wrote these books with such
literary capacity that it stimulated your
young minds to have what appears to have been
an authentic, precognitive experience.
I wouldn't attribute that to Adamsky because
of my intense interest in the field from 1947
on.
As a nine-year-old.
It's just that Adamsky was the first one to come up with alleged photographs and say,
I actually met him.
That's what grabbed me, even though I later,
of course, have completely rejected it.
It was that idea that you could get that close,
that intimately involved with aliens that
grabbed me.
Because I knew, as I said, even well before I
ever went to California, I mean, I was building
those rockets and some of them are pretty good sizes.
I mean, I was so much into space travel, and
wanting to be involved, I was going to become
a rocket engineer, but then once I had enough
experiences and Rex went right along, I mean,
he understood that once he had seen these things, I mean, when you see something like
that and you actually see this field moving
like a jellyfish around this thing, I'm sure
it affected Rex as much as I did, but it just turned me on like he plugged me in.
But I know for sure that was one that Rex was there, and with me from the time before
we left Los Angeles, he already was filled with it and felt, indeed, that if we went
out there and we had the confidence to invite
our friend Michael Robesicki, who was there
and saw it all.
So I'm glad to say that, in a way, Rex and I
never parted ways on this thing at the UFO.
He always accepted my UFO work because the things he had seen, and even after he was
out of the scene off into college and I'm encountering these things and then filming
these things with good witnesses, he was thrilled with this.
This was just fine, but it never distracted him from his parapsychological, which was
very important because I think he made, I
mean, in his psi-mediated instrumental response
or PMIR, as we always called it, I think he made a major contribution that people still
need to think a lot more about what he said and was finding about how this works from
inside of us.
I mean, I've experienced PMIR for years, and
it's just as natural as breathing almost,
and Rex experienced PMIR, too, at times, but
not as knowingly as I did, always my unconscious
seemed to be closer to the surface, although
Rex had his conscious into that and analyzing
that.
I had that helping me analyze these external things.
Sometimes you can get, I think, too intuitive
in trying to do your scientific research.
I think we need to keep a good balance, and I think my relationship with Rex helped me
keep that balance.
I think we kept each other in balance.
It kept him open to some things that otherwise,
in his distraction to the interior, you might
forget that something incredible is happening out there.
So we were a good balance all the way along.
I think you've described Rex as being more introverted, and you were more extroverted.
That's right.
Even as children.
That's an accurate description, very much so.
I mean, I was doing a lot more dating girls, and so Rex was more interior.
I don't recall.
I mean, he may have dated a few times, but I
don't recall him ever getting involved with
anybody until he met the girl from Sweden
who had read her book over there, and Birgert
Olsen was her name, and she came over and married him.
I just wasn't compatible with her.
I mean, she was my cup of tea, but she was Rex's cup of tea, and friends who know Rex
quite well, like one in New York I'm thinking
about, really feel that she was a tremendous
boon to him.
But her personalities were so different.
I had more experience with women, but it's weird to say he was like my other half, and
I think he recorded me as his other half, in a sense.
It's a strange thing to have another half, but
after all, we split from, I mean, according
to anyway, according to the doctor, my mother had gotten high blood pressure.
We had to be delivered quite a bit prematurely,
but he indicated, I guess, whatever it means.
We came from the same placenta or whatever.
He was sure we were identical twins, and I am too, because of our mental relationship.
Well, there's been quite a bit of work published
about telepathy between identical twins.
Yes.
One twin would always know if anything happened to the other two.
Yes, but I think we had a lot of that going on too.
I think he at times even knew things going on with me, but not as knowingly as I would
feel with him.
I was more conscious with telepathy, but he was definitely into it, and yes, there was
definitely a lot of telepathic interplay between
us, even when he's off in college and wherever
I was.
Now, at some point after you had rejected the UFO contactee movement that you and Rex
were both intrigued by, you set up the Association
for the Understanding of Man, and Rex had
some involvement there.
I know you published a journal, and one of the covers shows a picture of Rex standing
alongside some, looked like EEG recording instrumentation.
Yes.
He was not a part of the Association for the
Understanding of Man in the sense that he
was formed around and centered upon my psychic
work, my so-called readings and so on, because
he was into science and scientific, and we
wanted to try to take a scientific attitude,
even though we were promoting and publishing
things that came out of my unconscious.
I think there was a lot of good stuff, and my wife today was aware that there was, but
there was subjectivity to and belief in some
of these things for a while, and then gradually
I realized that so much of this that we might
think was the work of external, and yet when
things happen like the Blue Apple story, which
I've told to you, there certainly appeared
to be an independent existence there, but it didn't give Carlos Merida a name when
it came into his studio and told him how to change the study for a painting and call it
the Blue Apple, but anyway, the thing was in the Association, we deeply appreciated
the parapsychological and wanted to show the
scientific side of it and so on, as well as
our maybe more subjective side, and let's
say our side was impressionistic and his was
more realistic art, so to speak, when we were
dealing with this, but we were always harmoniously
cooperative, so I don't think he was ever on the board, he was certainly never on the
employ of the Association for the Understanding
of Men, but there was a strong respect, and
I think he respected my work, even though I feel confident that at least by the end
of the 70s that he was probably more skeptical
than I was at that time of the idea that any
independent beings could speak through me, I
think he understood it more as my unconscious.
At one point, isn't it the case that maybe before Rex had a university position that
he was actually working out of one of your offices?
Yeah, I think maybe he did for a while, yes, and
we find it, but he was doing parapsychological
research, he was never intimately involved
with anything about the readings or the alleged
beings that at times were speaking to me as
well as my unconscious, he didn't reject it.
Let me ask another question, to go back to the book you and Rex co-authored, Look Up,
there were multiple UFO sightings reported
in that book, not just the sighting of giant
rock.
Oh, yes, indeed.
Of course, reported there was even the one on
Padre Allen, which it turns out I was shocked
to see at the list of witnesses that we had out there.
We had quite a group from Brownsville that were out there with us too, and that wasn't
the kind of thing, if I remember correctly,
that any of us felt we had a telepathic message,
but we wanted to go out on South Padre Allen,
which would be very dark, no artificial lighting
at that time in the South Padre Allen, at
least for where we went, and I mean, the far
south end, yes, I'm sure there was, but we
went out to try to look for things, and whether
we tried to send a telepathic signal, I don't even recall that.
I could be wrong, but there were quite a few
of us, and we were watching the skies, I mean,
we got in a little, we did something we probably
shouldn't have, but some fishermen came in
and decided to do some surf fishing there that night, just north of us, they pulled
up.
Well, there's too many people out there, we didn't
know if they had guns or not, most fishermen
don't carry guns, they don't carry a rod and reel, but we felt that it might be, it
might discourage UFOs from coming around, or
at least if they wanted to have any interaction
with us, it might discourage that, so we went
up to them, and what we said is, I said, or
John said, I don't know, John McCourt, we're
out here conducting some experiments, and
there's some aspect of it that might be dangerous,
well, of course, if an alien spaceship coming
down, that might be dangerous, and so we weren't
too far from the truth, but maybe far from
it another way, but we wanted to scare them out of there, so we said, look, it'd be
better if you'd move at a safe distance, because it just might, or it might in some
way affect our experiments, but it might be dangerous.
So they left, but where they went, they headed
to South Padre ala and called the police.
They decided we might be doing something quite
illegal and dangerous out there, and so not
too long after that, here came the state patrol
car, up with the patrolman, the state patrolman,
John Hoyt, I believe was his name, and there
was a deputy sheriff, Steve Woods, and was
there one other?
I don't remember.
I've forgotten that affidavit is in the book, signed affidavit, and anyway, by the
time they arrived, they pulled up, and here's
this object hovering up there over the Gulf
of Mexico, and we said, what are you boys doing out here this time of the night?
We had no rod and reel with us, so they
knew we weren't fishermen, and I said, well,
we came out to see if we could see and maybe
even make contact with flying saucers, and
in fact, we have one that looked out the window,
looked out there, and the officer got out
of the car, and the deputy sheriff, whatever
he was, got out of the car, and he said, what
is that?
And I said, I told you, that is, we believe, an alien spaceship.
It's certainly not ours, and you'd have to read the book and see what happened.
I don't remember all the details of what happened,
but they finally began to get nervous and
said, well, we have to get out of here.
They decided to get out, and at that point,
I think I may have said, would you be willing
possibly to sign an affidavit to what you've seen?
And they said, well, we'll think about it, because I think maybe one of them said they
would, but eventually, so we came back into
town later after the event, there were three
officers that showed up in response to the call
from the fishermen, the concerned fishermen,
and driving the car was Texas State Highway Potomac, Don Hord, and his son, Ray Hord,
and so his Don Hord and Ray Hord, Don was the State Highway Potomac, and Ray Hord was
the deputy sheriff, and then there with him in the car was Steve Woods.
I think he was an undersheriff or something like that.
I forget what he was doing, but he was there.
And so finally, when we got together and called
them, when we went back to Brownsville some
days later, it was very nice of them.
Now, Don Hord, the State Highway Potomac said
he didn't want to sign an affidavit, that
he didn't consider that was official business
that night, but he didn't feel it was good
for him to sign an affidavit, but he'd be happy to pose in a photograph with his son
or father, whichever it was, Ray Hord, who was the deputy sheriff, who was willing to
sign an affidavit.
So Ray Hord, the deputy sheriff, and Steve
Woods, undersheriff or whatever he was, also
signed an affidavit, but the policeman in uniform let us photograph him as we showed
in the book.
So they were very cooperative.
I understood his position.
Back in those days, after all, Texas is bad enough today.
I'm kind of ashamed to admit I'm from there,
the way some things are going down there.
But actually, it was really, I think it was very
considerate of him to pose in the photograph,
and there were them to do the affidavit.
I mean, these affidavits go into some detail
about what happened, and so on and so forth,
and they're all notarized, and have the
officials seal the notary public that did this.
So it was quite a coup for ufology.
This was kind of a first, and we considered it a contact.
It certainly wasn't a physical contact, but
we kind of felt like we had possibly attracted
them out there.
I'm not sure that we had.
Maybe it was a coincidence, but it was a weird coincidence, if that's the case.
And little did I dream that it would someday
come on the full color illustration on the
front of a magazine called Fate Magazine, which was a good-sized magazine.
I mean, it had quite a circulation, and the newsstands, and the subscribers.
And to this day, I have a big enlargement of the whole color of the magazine up there
that I saw shockingly about 25 years ago, or 30 years ago.
I saw it advertised and bought it right away,
because I was shocked that here was a poster
being sold all these years later of this experience
we had on Padre Island way back in the fifties.
So that was what happened, and it may have been a psi-mediated instrumental response.
Maybe on the part of the, if you consider this
was an alien craft and they came in response,
I don't know why else they would show up out there.
I mean, it certainly wasn't anything else interesting out there, going on that island
that night in the middle of the night of a dark November night.
Well, to jump around a little, you and Ray,
while in high school, both competed in a science
competition for the state of Texas.
He, I gather, presented something about parapsychology.
I think he did.
I don't know, I don't recall what paper he presented, but there were several divisions
of the state, and of course I was in the physical
science because I was into rockets, and my
paper was called, Experiments with the Multiple Stage Principles of Rocketry.
Rex was, of course, in the, another side entirely,
like we're opposite sides of the brain, so
to speak, and he was in, I guess, the psychological sciences side.
And I suspect he did, I don't know what else it
would have spoken, unless it was a parapsychology.
I'm pretty sure it was, and I'm not putting
him down, but he didn't win a prize for his,
but that's not to be unexpected because, I
mean, after all, he was a pioneer, and showing
up in a high school in Texas, talking about
parapsychology, I mean, it was, it is commendable
that he was just daring to be there and give a talk on that subject.
It showed that he had the conviction of his research.
So it's great to his credit, even though they
